dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: We've waited long enough! For the last time, you will sign this order. Sir John Conroy, the Duchess’s Controller, handsome, vain arrogant, throws a cold look at the Duchess. Striding pas canopied four poster, he.comes to a smaller bed where Vic lies, flushed with fever, barely awake. He puts in front paper on a board and, with it, a pen.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I will not sign it.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: I say you will! He pushes the pen into her hand, holding it over the pape

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And I say I will not! With a supreme effort, she pulls her hand free and flings to the floor, pushing paper and board after it, as she co onto the pillows. His anger bursts as he pounces on it wi lifting his hand to strike her -

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Sir John. Baroness Lehzen, Victoria’s governess, stands, immobile, doorway. She is a dour figure next to the weak bird of pa that is Victoria’s mother.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Ah, Baroness, Sir John was just... She tails away. How can she justify the scene?

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Of course. Shall I...?

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: I'll do it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Good night, Mama. As she speaks, Victoria eyes her mother coldly. Pointing irony of this relationship is a nearby portrait of the Du her baby daughter. Things have clearly changed. The Duche nervously at Conroy and, after a moment of angry indecisi picks up the discarded pen and the paper. The Duchess lea passes Lehzen, who sinks low into a court curtsey. dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: My sister says she won't sign the order for a Regency. Stockmar is not surprised. Leopold waits for an explanati

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Why would she sign it? The Princess is nearly eighteen. Why would she sign away her own powers?

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Because she’s an ignorant baby! Because she needs guidance and time, to prepare for her role as Queen! And until she’s ready, my sister will take her place as Regent! The last is added lamely, which Stockmar almost reprimand

dialogues.text: Sir John Conroy would be Regent. Unfortunately, the Duchess is controlled by her Controller. This may be true, but Leopold is exploding with frustrati (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, I will not be cheated of all I've worked for, because of a stubborn child! Stockmar gives him a second to simmer down.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Conroy has over~played his hand. The Princess detests him. And the Duchess has also forfeited her daughter’s good will.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: According to your spy. Does Victoria know her governess is writing to you?

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Baroness Lehzen has a wide correspondence.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: So? What are you suggesting?

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: When the Princess succeeds to the Throne, she’ll turn away from anyone who's helped her enemies. It may be in Your Majesty's interest to consider abandoning Conroy and your sister before it’s too late, and instead support the future Queen. Leopold looks at him. Reluctantly, he gives a slight nod.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Of course the Duchess won't like it.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Baron, I was born the younger son of a penniless duke. Now, I am King of the Belgians. Such journeys are not managed without hard decisions. Besides, the cast of our play is not yet complete. And who controls a young girl most? A light dawns in Stockmar’s eyes. DELETED. page.7  5 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. EXT. dialogues.text: We'll spend two nights at Norris Castle, one for the local gentry, one for the town officials, then sail up the coast — He looks up. Victoria has entered the room with her dog. immediately to Conroy. At least the dog likes him. Victor curtseys to her mother.

dialogues.text: How did you come downstairs?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I walked.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Not alone?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No. Not alone. Lehzen was with me.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: And she held your hand?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: She did. Though why she still has to -

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: Sir John says ~

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lady Flora, but I was asking my mother. Oh. So these two are enemies. Conroy takes over.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: As much as possible, we want the people to know their new Queen.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: But why can’t we wait ‘til I am Queen? His Majesty clearly said - (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: At this, Lady Flora smirks at Conroy. Victoria notices.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: The King is jealous of your popularity and that’s why he doesn’t approve of your travels. It's no reason to give them up.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: On the contrary, it’s a very good reason. I do not wish to annoy my uncle.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: The King is old.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: He may be old, Sir John, but he’s not dead yet. | Sir John eyes Victoria coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white head of King William IV is shaking with anger a shouts at his Prime Minister. This is Lord Melbourne, a h witty, beguiling man in middle age. Queen Adelaide is wit

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Is there no limit to this woman's disobedience?

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: The Duchess wants the Princess to know more of the country.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The Duchess wants the country to know more of the Princess!

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Is it such a bad thing, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: To make her familiar, you mean? A popular girl who supports your ministry? You would defend it!

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELATDE
dialogues.text: I don’t think Lord Melbourne - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISZONS, &th aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You see how Conroy presents her? The young liberal in contrast to the old conservative? She is change and the thrill of the new, but I am stuck in-the mud of history. She is hope and the future, while I am despair and the past. She is life, Lord Melbourne, and I am death! He storms away for a moment. The Queen catches Melbourne’ shakes her head gently. She stands and walks over.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: There's nothing to be gained by shouting at the Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Nonsense. I feel much better.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELATDE
dialogues.text: And none of it is Victoria’s fault.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Maybe not. But she and her mother are tools in the hands of a man who knows how to use them. Mark my words. The reign of King Conroy is coming.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: My poor sister in law. What is the hold that wicked man. has over her? The question is rhetorical but the two men catch each oth and say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: What about her uncle in Brussels? Could he help?

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: King Leopold is as slippery as a barrel full of eels. If he did dislodge Conroy, it’d only be to tighten his own grip on the girl. He sighs and shakes his head. Melbourne is very smooth.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: King Leopold overestimates her power. As a constitutional Monarch, she cannot pass laws, to help or hinder him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Bug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Wo. We can’t make laws. But we can influence the men who do, That’s what he’s after! And so are you! Don’t tell me you’re not!

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: It is a Prime Minister’s duty to keep the Monarch informed of Parliament’s intentions. The sleekness with which he says this, reveals his plans.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Lord in your mercy, get me past May! That * way she’ll be of age and we’ll have killed off the Regency at least!

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: And what of the proposed journey? Might there not be some benefit in showing her to the people? Before Conroy has a chance to usurp her place? The King hesitates. Melbourne has a good point. As usual.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh, very well. Let England get a sight of her future Queen. But I'1l have no broadsides! No cannons and guns in salute. I’m still the monarch here! His face is as red as his hair is white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fusillade of cannon blasts into the air, smoke pouring mouths. On a raised and decorated platform, with the spar behind, Victoria receives the Freedom of a seaside town f lecal Mayor. A modest crowd watches them. The Mayor bows retreats, and Victoria steps back to where her mother, Co Flora and Lehzen are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Curtsey to them.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I have already curtsied.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Then curtsey again. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: With a smile, she gives a slight curtsey and is cheered.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: That’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: I will decide when it’s enough. But Victoria ignores him, looking around. *

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Victoria! Will you listen to Sir John! *

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Mama, I’m not running for election. I will be Queen not Prime Minister. With a last nod, she turns and starts to descend the step way to a waiting carriage. The others follow but, at the the steps, Conroy catches at Lehzen’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: I warn you. If you're her friend, don't set her against me. The Baroness does not answer but just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: You want to keep her for yourself but she needs me. If she tries to walk alone, she'll stumble in a month and fall within a year. For her own sake, don’t encourage her rebellion.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: I hope I encourage the Princess in all things, Sir John. She nods towards the crowd behind them.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Like it or not, they’re cheering her, you know. Not you. She descends the last step towards the carriage and Victo

dialogues.text: Lost in her thoughts, Victoria is looking at the sparklin

dialogues.text: Err... (He starts to answer in German).

dialogues.text: English! Always English. Albert nods. This is a tough discipline, but he will acce

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Lablache says that Mozart is the father of all music. The phrase has become her nickname for him. Stockmar is almost impressed. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Which opera does she like best?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Norma? Stockmar strikes the table sharply, with impatience.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR

dialogues.speaker: . LEHZEN

dialogues.text: Lying in wait, no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: She’s getting worse. So is Sir John. Lehzen tidies the bed clothes briskly.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: of course. In a few months I’1l be eighteen. If I don’t go mad first... All I ever seem to do is change my clothes and pray for freedom. She glances at the double portrait on the wall of herself baby, with the Duchess. She turns away to avoid looking a

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: It's only until your birthday. And don’t forget who championed you from the start. They are interrupted by the arrival of the Duchess and he She stops at the sight of Lehzen. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: I’ll say good night, Ma’am. She curtsies and leaves. The Duchess eyes her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: You two are so close. Anyone would think you were plotting treason. Don’t fuss me! She snaps at her maid who unfastens the glittering outer Here is the deconstruction of a Royal icon. The truth beh image. She entered as Her Royal Highness the Duchess of K silk, lace and diamonds, her hair dressed with feathers a We will leave her as a middle-aged woman, ready for bed. talks, the skirt comes away, then the embroidered bodice, corsets and layer upon layer of petticoats. She puts on a sit at the dressing table while the maid dismantles the h hair, removing the false switches, brushing it out.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: You still don’t look well. Maybe we should go away for August.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: What do you mean no?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: We missed the Queen's birthday. We will not miss the King’s. We have accepted. We're going.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Really, Victoria, don’t issue orders to me! I’m not a servant.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You've already disobeyed about the extra rooms. That‘s enough.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Don’t be absurd! Are we to live like rabbits, crammed in a hutch? Of course I “disobeyed”! :

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: We do live in a palace, Mama. We're a lot better off than most people. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: We live in an apartment in a palace which is far too small for our needs. The rooms I took were empty. Keeping us out of them was... almost immoral. As Sir John says - But at the mention of Conroy’s name, Victoria lies back.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: My dearest child, Sir John only wants the best for you. I wish you'd believe that.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I’m sure you do. page. 19 The Duchess gives a sharp look but, glancing at the maid, not reply, studying her face in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: I've invited the Coburg brothers to come and stay. You ought to know them better.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Well... because you should. Your Uncle Leopold thinks -

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I knew he'd have a part in it.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Really Victoria, there’s no pleasing you. You complain you've no friends but when I find you some companions of a suitable rank, you look as if I'd forced you to take medicine. Victoria just stares at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Mama, why do you treat me like a simpleton? Is it my fault? Was I unusually stupid as a child? There is a quality in her that almost frightens the mothe stares back, then takes it out on the luckless maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 15 16 17 Phe Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.2

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: TE you stick one more pin in me, I swear I shall cail the guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window, we see a carriage arriving. A footman down, and the two Coburg princes climb out. Conroy receiv Victoria is watching. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conroy and Lady Flora hover at the rear. Ernest walks wit Duchess. She ignores him, looking ahead at Victoria who i Albert. The Duchess, glimpsed behind the young couple thr the scene, conveys a powerful sense of Victoria's incarce

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Of the modern composers, I suppose Vincenzo Bellini is my favourite.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What a coincidence. So is mine. Which of his operas do you enjoy most? No, wait, let me guess. I Puritani?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, yes.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I used to like it, too. But now I prefer Norma. She's aware of what he is up to and has deliberately caug out. She takes a ball from her pocket and throws it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Dash! Fetch! Oh, fetch it, you silly dog! Albert picks up the ball, dancing along beside the dog, t with the ball just out of reach. But when he looks at Vic is not laughing, just watching. He gives the ball back to Their gloved hands touch. She pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Have I offended you in some way? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 18 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No. She continues for a few paces. Albert doesn’t know what t next. Then, suddenly, he decides to speak from his heart.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And Schubert. I like Schubert. I think perhaps you don’t, but... I do. She looks at him. She understands that this is true, and prompted. She decides to reward him for his honesty.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I don’t mind Schubert. Albert hesitates. He is pleased but he has surprised hims

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Good. He is very vulnerable. In fact, he has scored a point, wh know. But he doesn’t. After a second, Victoria smiles. INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. NIGHT. 18 Albert and Victoria play chess, again watched by the othe round the room. It is Albert's turn. He studies the board studies him. Conroy notices, but she gives him a cold loo their eyes meet, then lowers her voice.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Do you ever feel like a chess piece, yourself? In a game being played against your will?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Constantly. I see them leaning in and moving me round the board.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: The Duchess and Sir John?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Not just them. Uncle Leopold. The King. I’m sure half the politicians are ready to seize hold of my skirts and drag me this way and that, from square to square. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Then you had better master the rules of the game. Until you play it better than they can. Perhaps to her surprise, she likes this and smiles at him

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You don’t recommend I find a husband to play it for me?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I should find one to play it with you, not for you. : She nods. But the urge to tease is never far away.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Why don’t we ring for some music and then we could dance? We can read panic in Albert’s eyes. Victoria enjoys it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I’ve lately discovered the Waltz and I am quite in love with it. Albert looks to the Duchess. They have been caught out.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Waltzing is not really my forte.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh dear. What a shame. Victoria gives Albert a provocative glance. In spite of h she does like him. She lowers her voice.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You know the King wants me to marry my Cousin George? Albert, studying the board, does not rise to the bait. ALBERT . What’s he like at chess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lehzen waits by the stairs as Victoria leaves the drawing After a moment, Albert appears, closing the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.2

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Victoria. She stops, feeling Lehzen’s irritation.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It’s all right, Lehzen. Albert can take me up. You'll have to hold my hand. Mama insists. I hope you don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Not in the least. The Baroness hesitates then, defeated, goes on up.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What did you want to say?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Only that I understand more than you think. Of what your life is.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: My childhood wasn’t easy, either... I lost my mother when I was a boy.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I know. She died.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No. That is, she did die. Eventually. But she was sent away long before that. This does interest her. Much more than she expected.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: There was some... difficulty... It was all hushed up and no one talks of it now. But TI know what it is to live alone in your head. To smile when people are guessing your thoughts and never to give a clue of your real feelings. She appreciates his honesty. This is also her experience.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORTA
dialogues.text: Then you're right. We do understand each other. Did Uncle Leopold ask you to tell me that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 20 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.2

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: He said I was never to mention it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: How little he knows me. She turns towards the stairs, holding out her hand and he as he summons his courage to speak.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: May I write to you? She looks at him and without a word starts upstairs. He c her, waiting for her to speak. But the answer, when it co only a smile. It is more than enough. On the landing, the She looks at her hand, waiting for him to release it. He after kissing it in homage. Then she walks off down the p stopping once to look back. The fact is, he’s perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lehzen is waiting as Victoria walks in... a little out of with a smile on her face. She signs to her maid, Watson, her as quickly as possible.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: I expect you‘1l miss .the Princes when they’re gone, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Don't be impertinent. Ip Victoria winks at Watson as she is released from her stay

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: The untold luxury of being able to breathe again. Watson gathers up the discarded clothes and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Those boys pester you.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Give me some credit. You don’t think I've come this far to walk straight into another gaol?

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: You must marry one day. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 ai 22 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I don’t see why. And if I do, I'll please myself, not Uncle Leopold or the King or Mama or anyone else. Trust me. page. 25 20 Victoria takes a deep breath, then, dressed in a shift an an imaginary partner, she starts to waltz. What does she as she whirls round? Whatever it is, she’s more aware of on than Lehzen credits. INT. DUCHESS'S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. NIGHT. Albert comes back in, to find Ernest, reading.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST
dialogues.text: They've gone to bed. They said Goodnight. Listen to this. Right now, it takes a day er more to cross England in a coach. By train, the same journey will be achieved in three hours. Isn't that amazing? Trains will change everything. But there is no answer from Albert.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST
dialogues.text: Are you listening? No, he’s daydreaming. A waltz starts to play. INT. MUSIC ROOM. ROSENAU CASTLE. COBURG. GERMANY. DAY. The smiling profile of a Dancing Master in Close Up. He i 21 22 waltzing. As the camera slowly pulls back, we discover he with Albert, who feels ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: DANCING MASTER
dialogues.text: And one two three, one two three and face the window, face the wall, face the window, face the -— But Albert is lagging behind. The Master stops exasperate

dialogues.speaker: DANCING MASTER
dialogues.text: Your Serene Highness must learn to turn as you go.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Must I? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes. You must. Stockmar is watching. He is pitiless. Silently, Albert ta Master's hand and waist. The music resumes.

dialogues.speaker: DANCING MASTER
dialogues.text: And one two three, one two three -—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waltz still plays through this scene. By the carriage and the Duchess’s maid wait with a footman, as Victoria, mother, Lady Flora and Conroy emerge. Lehzen follows them

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Be on your guard.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: We are going to Windsor for my uncle’s birthday party.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: In the castle of the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Your enemy, Sir John. Not mine. The girl climbs in. He turns to the mother.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Agree to nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: What should I say about the rooms?

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: You needed more space. Appeal to the Queen. It’s ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Should I cultivate Melbourne?

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Smile on any politician you find there.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: I wish you'were coming with us. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 26A
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, &th Aug, 2007. page.2

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He does not answer but squeezes her hand as he helps her followed by Lady Flora. He steps back, catching sight of governess watching him.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: You're very intent, Baroness. Are you making a study of me?

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Someone should. She gets into the carriage as the footman and the maid cl behind. The coachman yells at the horses. The carriage mo INT. MUSIC ROOM. ROSENAU CASTLE. COBURG. GERMANY. NIGHT. The waltz plays on, as we see Albert, still practising hi Stockmar is with him. He has a pile of engravings on a ta he holds up to illustrate every question.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: The present Prime Minister? Albert glances over at the engraving as he twirls past.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Melbourne.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Lord Melbourne. The Liberal leader of the Whig Party. Who’ll probably be in power when the Princess succeeds. As he speaks, we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melbourne’s coach outside is in a torch-lit queue. He pas crowds outside, and enters the gates. . *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the entrance court, coachmen deposit their brillia and then drive off. Melbourne gets out of the coach. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He may be troublesome.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Because he puts the interests of England above those of Europe.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Which is bad?

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s not useful to us. He would not spill one drop of British blood to save a foreign throne. Melbourne walks into the castle. INT. MUSIC ROOM. ROSENAU CASTLE. COBURG. GERMANY. NIGHT. Albert seems perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: But why would he want to sdve a foreign throne if it wasn’t in England's interest? Stockmar stares at Albert. It is an intelligent comment.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: That is just the kind of thinking your Uncle Leopold is afraid of. EXT. ENTRANCE GATE. WINDSOR CASTLE. EVENING. 26c* Outside the gates, a coach passes quite close to the spec contains Victoria, the Duchess and Lady Flora Hastings.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Which is why he’s content to find his niece is the future Queen of England. Among the crowd is a young Londoner, Edward Oxford. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent room, a magnificent company, Monarchy at it Candlelight flickers on tiaras and gems . The King and Qu their guests. The Lord Chamberlain's voice rings out. * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: The Duke of Wellington. The familiar figure with his Roman nose strides in. We he continuing instruction of Stockmar.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In the public mind, the leader of the Conservative Opposition is their pet hero and Napoleon's conqueror, the grand old Duke of Wellington.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But not in fact.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No. The next Tory Prime Minister will be Sir Robert Peel. His voice is exactly in sync with the Lord Chamberlain’s.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN .
dialogues.text: Sir Robert Peel. A stiff and formal man enters the room. He advances towar Majesties and bows, then joins Wellington. We hear:

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Which side does Victoria favour?

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Whigs. She is a liberal. Or so she thinks. Above all, she favours Lord Melbourne. And Melbourne will take full advantage of it.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: The Duke and Duchess of Sutherland. Beyond Wellington and Peel, we glimpse the couple enter. Melbourne on the other side of the room. Wellington is go with Peel.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: You heard Conroy tried to force her agreement to a regency? Peel raises his eyebrows to signify that he has. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: I gather she wouldn’t sign it, sick as she was. That says something for the girl’s spirit.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: When she’s healthy and crowned, what chance would you give her Prime Minister?

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Her Royal Highness the Princess Victoria. Her Royal Highness the Duchess of Kent. The Lady Flora Hastings. The company breaks apart to make a channel for the women. the room, the Duchess of Sutherland whispers to Melbourne

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: Look at that demure little head. And all of us wondering what’s inside it.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: We'll find out soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert. continues at his lessons.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Lord Melbourne will make her fall in love with him. It is his method.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Don't underestimate Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Don't underestimate Melbourne. The comment is enough to make Albert stop dancing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King raises the curtseying Victoria and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLTAM
dialogues.text: My dearest niece. Archly, he indicates a spotty and awkward youth nearby. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to greet your cousin?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Good evening, George. It’s clear from her brisk nod that she isn’t interested.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: How can my little niece and nephew have grown up when I wasn't looking? Victoria slips her arm through her uncle’s.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Whereas you are quite unchanged and as handsome as ever. He laughs and draws her aside from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: If I put my head close to yours and speak softly, they'll suspect us of hatching a plot. As he talks, he does exactly this. The company is subdued curiosity. Victoria plays along.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And if I look a little surprised as I listen, they’1l know it. This she does, with her hand at her mouth. The company is falling forward in their efforts to hear. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ah, my dear, I wish we saw more of you. But then, nor you nor I are to blame for that. He gives a cold stare at the Duchess but she looks away. Further down the room, Wellington and Peel whisper softly

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: What do you make of the Conroy business? The Princess hates him. No doubt about it. They look at the Duchess, who is talking to the King.

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: I suppose they‘re lovers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page,

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: I suppose the girl thinks they are, which is more to the point. Across the room, the King’s voice is suddenly raised.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Madam, the plain fact is you have stolen seventeen rooms! The Duchess is uncomfortable with the sensation created.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: One cannot “steal” a room, Sir. The rooms are where you left them. But now they are used where before they were empty.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLTAM
dialogues.text: I see. So I have no say in my own palaces? Why not move in here and bring your Irish tinker with you? The Queen and I will be happy enough in the lodge! This is very rude indeed. The Duchess is icy in her reply

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: So would I, Sir. If I thought the people there would be polite to me! The Queen steps forward to head off further trouble.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELATDE
dialogues.text: We're going in. The Queen holds her husband’s arm and the procession form

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: How dare -

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Enough, my dear. You have exhausted the topic. She looks at him firmly. With a glare at. his sister-in-l steps off. Victoria follows, the cynosure of all eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our waltz becomies practical as an.orchestra plays. A tab long. sparkles with glass, silver and gold. Men and women alternately down its length with footmen behind their cha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 the Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 30 The King has clearly had more than enough to drink. Victo Melbourne. Further down the table, the Duchess of Sutherl the Duke of Wellington are neighbours.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Your next birthday will be quite a milestone, Ma'am. I hope it means we'll see more of you at Court. They glance across at the stony face of her mother.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I hope so too, Lord Melbourne.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: You know that if you should ever need an ally, you have one in me.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: A Prime Minister has more important calls upon his time. MELBOURNE . Not at all. I knew the late Duke of Kent well. Naturally I take an interest in his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You knew my father? This is a direct route te her heart. As he planned.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Is it difficult to speak of him?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No! I love to hear from someone who knew him! For I never did, you see.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: He was a great gentleman. Of that you may be sure.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Indeed I am.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: He was excellent company like his brother, the Regent. But not so extravagant. And he was as kind as his brother, the King... They both look over to where the red-faced, white-haired gabbling dementedly to his neighbour. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE,
dialogues.text: But not perhaps so... talkative.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You make him sound as if he were the best of them.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Oh, I think so, Ma'am. She glows with pleasure. They are watched by an eaves—dro Wellington and Duchess of Sutherland.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: Your leader is hard at work, Duchess. See him hover with his net to catch the pretty butterfly.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: And when your party is back in power, Duke, will you not do the same?

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: Not nearly as well as Melbourne. Unfortunately, I have no small talk and Peel has no manners. Which makes her laugh.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: And I'd have a hard time praising her father. The most brutal officer I ever encountered. He stops. The King, drunk and scarlet in the face, has ri feet. He signs for them to remain seated. The music stops

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: First, I thank you for your good wishes on my birthday. This is conventional enough. But his mood is darkening.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It has been a long life and an interesting one and I shall be content with only a short while more. Just enough to dispense with any thought of a Regency, so I may pass the Royal authority directly to that young lady - His voice is growing angrier as he points at Victoria. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 31 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.3

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: And not to the hands of a person now near me who is surrounded by evil advisers and who cannot act with propriety in the station in which she’s been placed! Suddenly the company sees that he is punishing his sister The Duchess tenses. He is very angry now.

dialogues.speaker: KING WILLIAM
dialogues.text: -I have been insulted - grossly and continually insulted! She has kept her daughter, my brother’s child, from my Court! But from now I’d have her know that I am King! And I will not be flouted or disobeyed by her ox by that jackanapes she keeps about her! He is shouting at the Duchess who blushes with rage. It i much. She stands, flinging her napkin down, knocking glas with a crash, and storms out, sending her chair flying. T total, pin-dropping silence in that vast chamber. Servant guests alike are frozen. Victoria blushes, trembling on t of tears. Wellington whispers to his other neighbour.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: Families. Who'd be without them? The Duchess of Sutherland smiles discreetly behind her fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria, dressed for bed, is sketching as Lehzen enters.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: How is she?

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: She wanted to leave tonight but they’ve persuaded her to stay until the morning. She's asked for your bed to be set up in her room. I'l] see to it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Can’t I be alone for one solitary night? She sighs. Lehzen says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: They act as if I had no mind of my own. But I know what lies ahead. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: 31B
dialogues.text: 32 33 Phe Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: All the more reason to listen to those who love you. She curtseys and leaves. Victoria, alone, goes to the win

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eleven year old Victoria speaks: fiercely to the night

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG VICTORIA, (AGED 11)
dialogues.text: I will be good. INT. A BEDROOM AT WINDSOR CASTLE. NIGHT. Back in 1836, Victoria looks out at the same sky and murm

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I will. INT. A WALL IN A ROOM IN LONDON. DAY. A cartoon of the row, with Duchess and King raging, and V cowering in the background, is pinned to a wall. INT. ALBERT’S ROOM. ROSENAU CASTLE. GERMANY. NIGHT. page. 36 31

dialogues.speaker: 31B
dialogues.text: 32 33 Discarded, unfinished letters have been thrown on the flo background, the door opens to reveal a man’s feet.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you get over there? The feet belong to Ernest. He looks at Albert, seated beh desk, writing. We see his back, not his face.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What? Like a vulture? To hover at the edge until the King is dead?

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST
dialogues.text: When he is dead, there'll be more than one vulture to contend with. What is it? Don’t you like her? Albert stops writing. He crumples the letter and throws i with the others. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 34 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yes, I like her. More than I dared hope. But it’s not up to me, is it? Albert finally turns to look at his brother.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What do you call’a man who waits for a rich woman to decide whether or not she wants him? Ernest says nothing. Albert nods.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: That’s the name I'd use, too. Ernest looks at the discarded letters on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST
dialogues.text: Then why not tell her how you feel? He leaves. Albert takes another sheet of blue paper... INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. DAY. 34 A fist slams down onto a letter on a table.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Don't you see what he wants! Victoria is with her mother and Conroy. Dash hovers nearb worrying a toy. The girl is attempting to keep her temper

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: He increases my income now I'm eighteen and he asks to see me at Court. What's wrong with that? .

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: The King wants to separate you from your mother! He is trying to control you, to take you from those whose sole aim is to protect you! Lehzen enters. Victoria stands, with a cool, studied calm

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: There’s no need to shout, Sir John. I’m sure the people of London will find out our business soon enough, without hearing it from your lips. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.3

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Tell her! Make her understand! Nervously, the Duchess tries to explain as Conroy crosses to a chair, struggling to control his anger.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Victoria, Six John only means that you're unprepared for the task that awaits you.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And if I am, whose fault is that! Conroy sits, then jumps up at once. He snatches one of Vi dolls and throws it to one side, losing what patience he walks back, shouting in her face.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: You're too young! You've no experience! You’re a china doll walking over a precipice!

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Then I must smash! For it’s too late to mend my ways now! So if you’ll excuse me -

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: But I will not excuse you! Seizing her arm, he flings her back roughly into the chai Victoria, this is a savage shock. The other women are stu dog snaris. The Duchess attempts to intervene.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Surely we don’t need - But he silences her, bending over the shrinking girl.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Now, here’s what you will do! First you‘ll refuse the money and demand instead that it be given to your mother! Next you will appoint me your private secretary, from today, and finally, you will agree to be co- regent with the Duchess until your twenty fifth birthday. Neither she, nor I, will accept less! He pauses, panting for breath, leaning into her face. Vic trembling with anger when she answers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 36 37 38 39 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, &th Aug, 2007. page.3

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You may do what you like with the money. Now, get out of my way! He makes a move to prevent her but she brings up her hand dismiss him so firmly that he drops back. She stands and the Duchess. Her voice is like ice.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: If you think I will ever forget that you sat by silent and watched him treat me thus, you're dreaming! She goes, followed by Lehzen and Dash. The Duchess looks who slams the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria walks into her room in a fury, slamming the door her as violently as Conroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two footmen on duty and a butler walking through, hear th the doors. They look’at each other, half enjoying the sti INT. DUCHESS'’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. DAY. 37 The door bursts open. Conroy looks up, startled. He stand Albert walks across the room. Until he stops and punches full in the face. INT. VICTORIA’S BEDROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. NIGHT. 38 Victoria embraces Albert. He comforts her, enjoying the f of her skin as a haunting melody played on a piano is hea INT. ALBERT’S ROOM. ROSENAU CASTLE. GERMANY. NIGHT. 39 Albert is still enjoying Victoria's scent on a letter in Bater, seen from behind, Albert writes at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My dear Victoria, if it is ever within my power to assist you, you know you have only to ask... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: 40D
dialogues.text: 41 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, eth Aug, 2007. page.4

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We go over his shoulder to reveal a sheet of blue paper o he's writing. Underneath it, we see some music entitled “ Song.” But the camera doesn’t stop on his letter, nor on from Victoria, but rather on the envelope that sits next franked with the mark of the Belgian Royal Household.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through flashbacks, we follow Victoria’s letter: Victoria hands her letter to a Footman. It is addressed t in Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Footman gives it to the Duchess of Kent. * MONTAGE.. INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON. DAY. 4 The Duchess of Kent inserts it in another envelope and se with wax, imprinting it with her cypher. * MONTAGE. INT. GALLERY. LABKEN PALACE. NIGHT. 40c King Leopold passes the letter to Stockmar. MONTAGE. INT. KING LEOPOLD’S LIBRARY. LAEKEN PALACE. NIGH Stockmar puts it back in the envelope and seals it. We no understand why there are two seals on the envelope. *

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: How should we play it? INT. KING LEOPOLD‘'S LIBRARY. LAEKEN PALACE. DAY. Al King Leopold is by the window in this splendid apartment, out at the gardens. He is restless.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: We've thrown over Conroy. Now go after Melbourne. Make him an ally. He’ll be less on his guard if he thinks you’re a friend. Leopold nods to dismiss the adviser but as Stockmar bows. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: al 42 43 44 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page. CONTINUED: 4l

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: And Albert? Is he ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert is playing the piano. It is the same melody that w the previous scenes.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He may be. But she isn’t. Let her enjoy succession and the freedom it will bring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria’s impressive collection of dolis fill the frame.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We must wait for disillusion, and the loneliness that follows. Victoria is being dressed by Watson as she finishes readi letter on Albert's blue paper. She looks inside the envel finds the musical piece: “The Swan Song” by Schubert. It time, but it does finally make her smile. INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. DAY. 44 Melbourne is with Victoria. He stands. She sits.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Is there really no compromise? Not private secretary but something harmless? We must keep up the look of the thing - She cuts him off. She is full of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I tell you, Lord Melbourne, his behaviour to me ~ Cheeks flushed, she struggles to control her rage.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Makes it impossible to keep him in any post near-my person. Any post whatever.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: You don't think it more dangerous to cut him loose? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I can’t help that! I know things - When she has recovered, she speaks again. Very calmly.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Things that mean I could never have confidence in him... I see I must endure Lady Flora. Mama can hardly appear at Court without a lady-in-waiting. But I draw the line at Conroy. Once I am Queen, I do not wish to look upon his face again.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: We can't prevent the Duchess from leaving him in charge of her own affairs.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Then that will be her mistake. Not mine.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Very well. He bows. The interview is at an end.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: And Ma'am... you needn’t worry. I‘1l be your private secretary. To begin with, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lord Melbourne. That is a great comfort to me. For the first time, she is smiling. He goes towards the d adding, as an afterthought:

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: We must consider the new appointments. Your lJadies-in-waiting, and so on... What about the Duchess of Sutherland for Mistress of the Robes?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: TI don't really know her.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: As to that, Ma’am, she’s a great friend of mine. You'll like her enormously. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 45 46 47 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I should be lost without your guidance. I hope you know how very grateful I am.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Don’t give it a thought, Ma'am. I'll draw up a list. She smiles. He bows, and leaves. Victoria, left alone, pu hands on her sides, breathing against her tight stays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the door, Melbourne stands in triumph. He has ach first goal of the next reign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter addressed to Albert in Victoria's writing is giv

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: As a matter of interest, will a time come when I read them first? Albert is with Stockmar, who is immune to this kind of th

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: You'll enjoy this one. She has a real flair for description.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Any progress against Conroy?

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Very much so.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is madness! INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. DAY. 47 Conroy paces the room. The Duchess is wringing her hands. sits patiently in front of them and says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: She’s only a child!  48 49 the Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child is smiling as, all alone, she writes to Albert.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If she is a child, it could be said Ma'am, that you have kept her so. INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. DAY. 49

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: A mother’s duty is to protect her. daughter's innocence.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: A mother’s duty is to prepare her children for the lives awaiting them.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: But what will people say? Surely to exclude us entirely will launch the new reign in a cloud of scandal!

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: They'll say the Queen and her mother do not always agree. These things happen in the best families.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: But where am I to live? Am I to be abandoned here? Or must I beg along the highways for a crust?

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: You'll move into the Palace with the Queen, but she has arranged a separate apartment for you. It will allow you both more privacy.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: I don’t want privacy from my own child!

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Nevertheless you shall have it. The Duchess produces a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: You are cruel, Sir. You prefer to break my heart than plead my cause. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Bug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: And when King Leopold learns of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King Leopold is finishing a letter that he gives to Stock hear Melbourne’s and the Duchess’s voices.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I am here this morning at his express command.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My brother knows that I'm to be cast into the wilderness? 51 INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. DAY. 5 This is a blow. They are both completely stunned.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: You're lying!

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: You are out of your depth, Sir John. It has made you forget yourself.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: I understand your game, my lord. You want to be her father, mother and who knows what besides... Despite himself, Melbourne registers this. He stares at h

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: You won’t succeed. You do not know her, whatever you may think. He will not answer. Conroy takes advantage of the cooler

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Surely, if I’m not to be her secretary, there must be something else - Melbourne cuts him off with a raised palm.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: I see I am not speaking clearly. How can I put this? You have played the game...  52 53 54 55 56 fhe Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. INT. VICTORIA'S BEDROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. NIGHT. As we cut back to Victoria writing her letter, we see her pronouncing in sync with Melbourne:

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ++. and lost. INT. STAIRCASE. ROSENAU CASTLE. COBURG. DAY. Albert looks up from his letter at Stockmar, who smiles. INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. DAY. page. 46 52 53 54 The Duchess looks at Conroy and then at Melbourne. Melbou at the Duchess and then at Conroy. INT. VICTORIA'S BEDROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. NIGHT. 55 Victoria smiles a victorious smile as she ends her letter firm full stop. Her pen on the paper makes a sound that p the moment. She feels good. So do we. INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. DAY. The tone is abrupt. Melbourne bows to the Duchess.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Good day to you, Ma’am. He has gone, leaving her speechless. She reaches out for hand but he is furious. He walks away from her.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: You will still run my household.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Don’t think it’s the end! It’s not at all the end! 7

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: When you talk like that, you frighten me.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Good. 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 58 59 60 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria puts her letter for Albert in an envelope. Just sealing it, she looks at a little scent bottle. Smiling a absurdity, she touches the stopper to the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stockmar is with Albert, who has read Victoria's letter.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: But she does not summon me.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Not yet. But she will. He bows and goes, leaving Albert alone, disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are behind Queen Adelaide who watches from a high wind below, a coach pulls away from the castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sleeping Victoria is being shaken by the Duchess who there in her nightclothes.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Victoria. Liebling... The girl opens her eyes and the two women, watched by the dolls on the bedside table, stare at each other. It is the hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother and child, hair loose, are at the top of the stair Duchess, in a heavy, damask dressing gown, is in contrast Victoria, who wears a white, lace-trimmed peignoir. As th down, the Duchess holds out her hand and Victoria takes i complaint. At the bottom, in the hall, stands a footman w tousled hair who has struggled into some part of his live

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Where are they? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 61 62 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: In the drawing room, Ma'am. As Victoria walks forward, her mother makes as if to acco but the daughter stops her with a look and goes alone. * INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. DAWN. 61 In the flickering light of a single candelabra, Victoria through the shadows across the floor. She stops. The arch kneels. Then the tall statesman drops to one knee. Reachi takes her hand and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Long live the Queen. It is both moving and awe-inspiring as the Courtier and t of the Church bow in deference to this tiny figure in a s nightdress, with her shimmering hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria comes out. The Duchess and the others hover. Alr clear that Victoria’s manner has changed.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I'm going back to bed. I imagine Lord Melbourne will be here quite early. Lehzen, you can see that he has everything he needs if I'm not ready to receive him.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Of course, Your Roy - She stops.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: O£ course, Your Majesty. She goes down into a deep curtsey as Victoria walks by. A moment, so does her mother and finally Lady Flora sinks t floor. Victoria walks to the stairs. The Duchess stands.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Wait. I'll hold your hand.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No, thank you, Mama. Her voice does not brook any argument. She pauses. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 63 64 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.4

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And Lehzgen, in the morning could you arrange for my bed to be moved into a room of my own?

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Well, there’s no great -

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: As soon as possible, Lehzen. I thought you'd understand, Mama. I’m Queen. Your work is done. Watched by the women, she climbs the stairs. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria, in black, is mouthing words, before a mirror. T of Sutherland enters. *

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: The Council is assembled, Your Majesty. Lehzen, also in black, is arranging her skirt. Watson and maid are present. The doors are being opened. Victoria do move. Then she locks at Lehzgen, as a child would look to for help. Lehzen nods and Victoria starts to walk out the Watson chases after, handing Victoria some lace mittens s forgotten. Victoria and the Duchess then exit. We move al passages until we reach a door in front of which stands L Chamberlain.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Is your Majesty ready? She nods. A footman opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Her Majesty the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a crimson room, lined with huge paintings in gilded fr many men, old and middle aged, ranged round a table cover green baize. They are in mourning and they stand as the s figure enters, goes to the throne, bows, and sits. On the throughout, the men tower over her. She‘s nervous but als dignified as she reaches for her speech, placed nearby, c gently to clear her throat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 : The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It is with a sense of reverence and honour that I address you, my Privy Councillors, as your Sovereign and Queen. I mourn sincerely the death of my dear uncle, the King, but I know I may count on you to serve me as loyally as you served him. She clears her throat again. The men’s eyes are brimming.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I am young but I am willing to learn and I mean to devote my life to the service of my country and my people. I look for your help in this. I know I shall not be disappointed. Thank you. * She finishes and holds out her hand to the nearest man wh understanding what is required, sinks to one knee.

dialogues.speaker: COUNCILLOR
dialogues.text: I, John, Earl of Derby, swear allegiance to my Sovereign Lady, Queen Victoria, to live and die your liege man. So help me, God. Watching at the far end of the room, Wellington stands wi Melbourne and Peel.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: A welcome change after all those fat, old men.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: The country's half in love with her already. I know I am.

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: She starts on your watch, Lord Melbourne. Guard her well and keep her safe from harm. Melbourne almost laughs as the Lord Chamberlain nods. It turn.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: I, William, Viscount Melbourne, swear allegiance to my dear Sovereign Lady, Queen Victoria, to live and die... The young Queen smiles upon him, her kneeling, surrogate Wellington observes this with a look to Peel.  65 66 67 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. The Queen emerges soberly, to join the Du Sutherland who have waited outside. The door is shut. Vic herself with satisfaction and skips off down the passage merry child. Thunder rumbles. *

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Always remember, you are first a Coburg!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King Leopold is angry. Outside, it is lashing with rain.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: The King of the Belgians is a Coburg! The King of Portugal is a Coburg! The Queen of England's mother is a Coburg! And you are the next piece in the game! Prince Albert is smiling.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Nothing, Sir. You just reminded me of something Victoria once said.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: I'm glad she makes you smile. Now go to England and make her smile!

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, if I may... Leopold glares at the baron but he nods.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: We have only to be patient. The young Queen is testing her wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buckingham Palace A mounted soldier presents his sword as Victoria steps ou coach and looks at her new home. Lord Chamberlain welcome (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, &th, Aug, 2007. page

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She walks through an alley of Cold stream guards, all sal presenting arms.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: She won’t wish to clip them quite yet.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Tf she flies free she may get away.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Wait ‘til she flies through a storm. But Victoria is glad to be in the right place at the righ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria enters the wide, light, and, above all, free hal new home. *

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE, (V.O-.)
dialogues.text: I’m sad you don’t care for poor George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria is walking with Queen Adelaide, both in mourning capers along in front.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I like George.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELATDE
dialogues.text: But not in that way. Victoria's silence confirms this.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELATDE
dialogues.text: What about Leopold’s candidate?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: That's just it. There’s nothing wrong with Albert. Nothing at all... Her mind wanders slightly, then returns to make the point

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: But he is Uncle Leopold's choice. I can’t marry the man they want me to marry!

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Every suitor will have strings attached. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, &th Aug, 2007. page.5 68

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Can't I be my own mistress for a while? Haven’t I earned it? And dear Lord M.'s so very kind. I couldn’t have a better tutor.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: You may dream of independence but you won't get it. From now on, everyone will push and pull you for their own advantage, Melbourne More than the rest. Just remember you're a queen, he’s a politician. And politicians, whatever their creed, always resent a monarchy. They pass through. You stay. So just keep “dear Lord M.” in his proper sphere. Something in this troubles Victoria, which Queen Adelaide Victoria ¢

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: He's already chosen the new Household.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: What? You mean your ladies~in-waiting? Did you ask him to? learly feels she’s on weakening ground.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: TI couldn't do it. I don’t know anyone. I’ve been living at the bottom of a well.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I warn you, the public won't stand for a liberal Court, when they elect a conservative government.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It's not my business to pander to Tory sensibilities.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELATDE
dialogues.text: But it is your business to make the system work! Victoria looks at her aunt sharply. Adelaide cools down.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: If Melbourne's packed the palace with the wives of his supporters, there'll be trouble when he loses office. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 69 70 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 6th aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Then let’s hope he never does! Queen Adelaide’s expression is not reassuring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria comes in. The Duchess of Sutherland is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: The Prime Minister is here, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Duchess. They start to walk away from camera, down the passage tog

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Have I ever thanked you properly, for accepting the post? I'm afraid it will involve a good deal of inconvenience.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: To be Mistress of the Robes is a great honour, Ma’am. I’m only anxious to be worthy of it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Lord Melbourne says you will be perfect.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: Lord Melbourne doesn't know everything.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh, I think he does. They laugh. Victoria notices a nearby flower arrangement. INT, VICTORIA’S SITTING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. 70 Victoria has now a rosebud tucked into her bosom. On a ta doll collection reminds us of the earlier life. Victoria at her feet, as she talks to Melbourne. He (always) stand

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: The Duchess of Sutherland says the young leave prison worse than they went in. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Indeed, Ma’am. But there are many places one leaves worse than one went in. I always leave a ball-room worse than I came in. Are there to be no balis in future? victoria laughs. But something is troubling her.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: About my ladies-in-waiting...

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: I'll bring the list later today, Ma'am. They’ve all accepted. Oh. The Queen is slightly wrong-footed.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Only my aunt advised me not to be too partisan in my choice... She laughs gently as if this is a joke. He is very smooth

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: With respect, Ma'am, I think I understand these things as well as the Queen Dowager.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: T know that, of course.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: And we want friends around us as we begin our labours, surely? We mustn’t find Sir John Conroy sneaking back to the table.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No! Not if we have to line up every friend we both possess, in triple ranks! She is distracted and Melbourne moves matters briskly alo

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: It’s very cold. Why haven't they lit the fire?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It seems fires are laid by the Lord Steward’s department but lit by the Lord Chamberlain’s. No one knows which footmen should do it. It’s not very sensible. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Well, if it’s the way things are done, I should leave it alone. Victoria is troubled by this.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: But we must improve where we can! If I’ve discovered anything from touring England, it’s the suffering that needs my help.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Never do good, Your Majesty. It always leads to scrapes.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Really Lord Melbourne. That’s not what is . preached from the pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Exactly why I never go to Church, Ma'am. One hears such extraordinary things. As she laughs again, there is a noise outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: T want to go in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duchess of Kent and Lady Flora are outside with two f

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, Ma'am, but Her Majesty is with the Prime Minister and cannot be disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: That won't apply to her mother! She steps forward to reach for the door but he intervenes

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: What a splendid example for the Nation! Fuming, they retreat, watched by the servants. The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, &th Aug, 2007. page. 72 INT. VICTORIA'S SITTING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. The Queen and Minister are almost guilty.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You must think me very harsh.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Not in the least. The Duchess is a difficult woman.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Stubborn, self-centred and always right!

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: My mother was the same. But at least she was intelligent. Which elicits a guilty smile. She glances despairingly at letters covering her writing table.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You'd think Mama was at the North Pole from the number of letters she writes! Before I can answer one, she sends four more! Melbourne notices a blue letter under the desk. He retrie studying the writing which is different from the rest.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I’ve made no promise to him. Victoria is actually embarrassed. Her tone is defensive.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: But sometimes I feel quite alone in the world.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Never while I’m here, Your Majesty. Their eyes meet. Victoria blushes. 73 INT. ALBERT’S ROOM. ROSENAU CASTLE. COBURG. DAY. 73 Albert reads a letter. Stockmar, with him, holds the enve

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Plenty of praise for Lord Melbourne and not much of anything else. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 74 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Albert stands, throwing the letter down.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Everything comes to he who waits.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And if nothing comes, what then? You‘ve played with me, Baron, you’ve made me your * wax doll, all to please one woman. But what * if I do not please her? What’s to become of * me, then? Stockmar is very calm, as he comes to a decision. *

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: You do please her, Sir, but perhaps it is * time to remind her why... You will attend * her Coronation as the representative of His Serene Highness, the Duke of Coburg.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: But my father is planning to go, himself.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Then he can un-plan it, can’t he?

dialogues.speaker: INT, WESTMINSTER ABBEY. DAY. 74
dialogues.text: Victoria, in the lilacs and mauves of half-mourning, is w Melbourne in the Abbey. The Duchess of Sutherland, Lady T and Lady Portman, her new ladies in waiting hover behind.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Queen Elizabeth never married and it didn’t spoil things for her. She looks at him but says nothing. They stroll to where t Coronation Chair stands. She touches it silently.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: You're familiar with the Coronation Chair and the ancient Stone of Scone.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Familiar yes, but quite in awe. She steps forward to touch the carvings, to be alone with of her ancestors, then turns back to Melbourne. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I’m terribly afraid of disappointing. On the day. I so want to do it perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: The prison of monarchy, Ma’am, is that everything you do must be perfect. Which is true enough to make her solemn. He reassures her

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Just be yourself. Your instincts are always to your credit. Comforted, she looks round and catches sight of some roug workmen who have gathered to see her.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: They are preparing the Abbey for the ceremony. I’m told they asked permission for a glimpse of Your Majesty. She smiles and waves. They are shabby and poor, but they back, calling God’s blessings on her head. Visibly touche turns to Melbourne. VICTORIA ‘ I do want to help them, whatever you say. And not just the labouring poor, but the lost, the hungry, the homeless... Whose business is it to see to their welfare?

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: These things are best left to develop naturally. Interfere, and you overturn the cart.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Prince Albert doesn’t agree. He’s made a study of the working man’s conditions and he’s full to the brim with ideas for their improvement.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Indeed, Ma'am? How inspiring. He sounds ready. to take control at the first opportunity. He makes no further comment but his words sink in.  75 76 77 78 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page. INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. NIGHT. 75 As the Duchess arrives, Conroy hides a decanter of whisky cabinet. Quickly, he takes a peppermint. :

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: You may not accompany me to the Proclamation Ceremony. You may not attend the Coronation. He stares at her, not giving a reaction. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ceremony we witnessed at the start is almost over. Vi crowned Queen. But this time, it is from Albert’s point o sees a man sleeping, the Coronation ring forced on the wr finger, a peer taking a sandwich from a page who’d hidden underneath the coronet he’s holding, and a lord falling d stairs before the Throne. This is quite different from Me vision. Albert watches as the Prime Minister catches the eye and mouths “Perfect.” Albert takes in Victoria’s deli smile, and ponders what he is up against.
