Bells are ringi Zadok The Priest reaches its climax. INT. DUCHESS'S DRAWING ROOM. DAY. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. Conroy is drinking. He stares down through a window as we medley of cheering crowds, ringing bells and Zadok The Pr the song ends, he suddenly smashes his glass in the firep

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prime Minister stops, astonished. Then he smiles and throat. Victoria, in her white dress, is giving Dash a ba

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Don’t look so surprised. A Queen has many different duties.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: It is heartening to know she will not neglect the least of them. Even on Coronation Day. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 78 79 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I don’t think Dash would allow it. She holds up the soapy dog and kisses it on the nose.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Try to rest before the ball.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I will. Since I firmly intend to dance until dawn.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: You've plenty of Royal partners to choose from, for once. But if he is fishing, she does not rise. Instead she towe and lifts it as her partner in a waltz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Coronation Ball is as glamorous as the ceremony. Jewe uniforms, orders, feathers, an orchestra playing. The dan is empty. For the first time since the King’s death, Vict colours and the effect is enchanting. She is surrounded b princes. Melbourne hovers, watched by Albert from the edg crowd. The Lord Chamberlain bows. *

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN .
dialogues.text: If Your Majesty would open the ball... Victoria looks at the men around her. Who will have the h ox three look hopeful. So does Melbourne. Then she spots We stay on her face as she seems to be pulled magically t middle of the dance floor by a man. She whispers.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is wise? Finally, we see that it is Albert, as handsome as always. her hand and waist. The music starts and he steps off, fi taking the lead. They spin smoothly round. They’re so goo together, nobody wants to join them and spoil it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You've paid attention to your teachers.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I might say the same for you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 80 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They are beautiful to watch and that’s what we do as they moment in silence. After a while, we dissolve to: LATER: They are not alone on the floor any more. Other gu surround them as they all waltz in harmony. Then the musi

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: It’s been quite a day. Are you tired?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Not very. I‘m stronger than I look.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Not stronger than you look to me. She quite likes this answer. He never diminishes her.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: How long are you in London?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Only ‘til Friday. Then home via Brussels. Uncle Leopold must first have his report. They share a smile at this as a quadrille starts to play.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh dear. A quadrille with the Prince of Prussia next. My poor little toes. I feel sorry for them already. A tall man, his chest covered in medals, arrives to claim a click of his heels and a bow. Reluctantly, Albert lets walks back across the floor, he feels Melbourne’s eyes on These two are aware they are rivals for the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter addressed to King Leopold is passed from her han Albert and Victoria are walking. Lehzen and the Duchess o Sutherland hover on the terrace, watching.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Thank you for being my messenger. I only hope I’ve given him enough detail. You can fill in anything I’ve missed.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: He takes a great interest in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Don't I know it! If you heard the questions he asks in every letter! Like a never- * ending examination! Lord Melbourne calls him - She breaks off, embarrassed at her indiscretion.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What about Lord Melbourne?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Never mind. It doesn’t matter... Well... T wish you a good journey... ‘She hesitates. He takes her hand. But he holds on to it.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Victoria, I would so much like... She waits. On the terrace, her ladies have risen. It is t her next appointment. Albert ends as best he can.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I would like to be useful to you. If there is ever an opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I know you would. And one day I may take advantage of your offer. She looks into his eyes, not wanting her words to hurt hi

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: But not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leopold is clutching the letter, raging at Albert and Sto

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Have you read this?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: It seems she does not think it appropriate to discuss politics “in our otherwise delightful correspondence!” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: B4
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Which was dictated by Melbourne.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Damn it! I am King of a country that is eight years old! I need help, and it’s my * niece's duty to give it! Do something!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Uncle, please calm down. The Baron is not a * magician. *

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Melbourne guards her like a lion. I can't * get past him. *

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Then get him past Melbourne! Get him into her bed! He points at Albert who is extremely uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: We’ll soon see if she still takes Melbourne’s dictation! Enraged, he tears the letter to shreds. Albert leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bursts open. Albert strides in, going directly t Melbourne who looks up, startled. Albert stops in front o takes his glove off. And slaps him across the face. INT. ALBERT’S ROOM. ROSENAU CASTLE. COBURG. NIGHT. 83 Albert slaps the shutter of his bedroom window as he stan looking out into the night. He slaps it again and again.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What are you playing at? Ernest.is in the doorway, looking very tired and not very Albert cannot put his angry thoughts into words. INT. VICTORIA'S DRESSING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. NIGHT. The Queen is being dressed again. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 85 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Has anyone ever reckoned the hours we waste, with this endless changing of clothes? .

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: And if you didn’t, Ma’am, what would I .do then? Which Victoria had not considered. Watson holds a scent b Victoria hesitates, then waves it away. She will keep it Albert. INT. WHITE DRAWING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. NIGHT. Victoria sits at dinner with a party of about twenty. The her mother, the Duchess of Kent, seated far away.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: So, Duke, how was Paris?

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh, as charming and as dangerous as ever.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Lord Melbourne says French doctors kill their patients. English ones just let them die. This is greeted with a respectful laugh.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: I thought he might be here tonight.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: He’s thrown me over for Lady Holland. She says it smiling but it clearly rankles.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: I expect Your Majesty will miss him.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Not too severely. He’ll be back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: No, I meant when he’s out of power.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: page. 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 86 87 88 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her tone begets a tremor of unease. Her mother looks down at her. Wellington had no intention of starting this.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: Well, only... I don’t mean to crow. I just thought it was common knowledge that he’s about to lose the vote... He tails away. Every eye is on the Queen. The great room silence. But she is perfectly composed when she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Parliamentary democracy is Britain's greatest gift to the world, Duke. Even if sometimes it can be rather trying. They laugh more than her quip deserves. The danger is ove Victoria turns pleasantly to her other neighbour, without the look of compassion in her mother’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria is standing by the window, her face turned away.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Schatzi? Victoria glances towards the voice. In the shadows, Lehze standing, motionless. She holds a tray with some milk aga

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: What is it? Victoria turns away again, to hide her face. Like a silen stalking beast, Lehzen glides across the room, waits for and then slides her arm round the girl. After a moment, V shoulders start to heave.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: There, there... Never mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duchess approaches her daughter’s door. She would kno sound of crying makes her hesitate. INT. VICTORIA’S SITTING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. NIGHT. 8 Lehzen is holding the glass to Victoria’s lips. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 88 89 90 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Just a sip... now another... She glances at the table of dolls and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Oh, look. Miss Agatha is playing up again. She’s just as naughty as ever! A snuffling Victoria reaches out to stand the fallen doll

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Dearest, darling Lehzen, you won't desert me, will you?

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Never, mein liebe schatzi. Never. The Queen is a child once more. As Lehzen intended. Throu mirror, we see Victoria’s door gently closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duchess of Kent is visibly hurt. Her role has been us Dash’s head appears in the ajar door. The Duchess leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exasperated Peel is alone with Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: But Sutherland is a prominent Whig! So is Portman! Every one of your ladies is the * wife of a friend of Lord Melbourne? Surely you can see how it looks?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You should not set such store by appearances, Sir Robert.

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: I’m only asking for a token, Ma’am. For two ladies, or even one, who supports my cause. Otherwise, it must look as if Palace and Parliament have fallen out! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Let me understand you. Are you telling me it is now the Prime Minister who selects my household? Has the law changed in this regard?

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: Well, no, Your Majesty, but -

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Then there cannot be much more to be said on the subject. Victoria rings a small bell.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Good day, Sir Robert. And could you please ask Lady Portman to come in, as you leave? * The interview is over. He is boiling, but he bows and goe footman opens the door. Lady Portman enters. *

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I wonder if you could have a note delivered * to Lord Melbourne?

dialogues.speaker: LADY PORTMAN
dialogues.text: Of course, Ma’am. Victoria is satisfied, but the lady-in-waiting is worried

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What about Albert? 91 INT. THE DUCHESS’'S DRAWING ROOM. KENSINGTON PALACE. N We are close on Albert’s face. He is concentrating.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Should he go now? Is it time?

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Let her first taste unpopularity. Then we'll see what she will take to ease the pain. Albert and Victoria are playing chess. She picks up a whi and starts to remove a black Castle -

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you quite sure, Ma’am? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 92 93 94 95 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks up, hesitating. Melbourne, Leopold and Stockmar the chimney-piece, watching the game. She pauses, with th in her hand, looking back to Albert.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Make your move. She places the Knight on the board and starts to pick up Castle, when her wrist is seized. She looks up, startled, that Albert has become Sir John Conroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria starts awake. Watson is setting a tray of tea th her bed. And a newspaper. Victoria reads the headline.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSBOY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Constitutional Crisis! Queen flouts Prime Minister!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy is selling papers, with headlines as loud as he is.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSBOY
dialogues.text: Threat to bring down Tory Government! Palace at War with Parliament! Edward Oxford, among others, is buying a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another cartoon is pinned to the wall. An arrogant Victor an anguished Peel, while leaning on Melbourne’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You reign by right of Parliament! And you must work with the voters’ choice!

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But Lord M. says ~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria is with Queen Adelaide, arguing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 96 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Melbourne says what suits his interest! He’s used you to punish his enemies without thought of the damage to the Crown! My dear... She takes Victoria’s hand, her tone becoming tender.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I wish you had an ally to help you in this.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I have Lehzen. I have Melbourne. Until this morning, I thought I had you!

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I mean an equal, and of your own age - But, somewhere outside the carriage, a man is shouting.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Queen is in the clutches of Melbourne the Great Seducer! Sheltering behind the curtains, Victoria and her aunt gla They are at Speakers Corner and a wild-eyed fellow on a s addressing a modest crowd. He hasn’t finished.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: And when he is silent, who does she listen to? Her German mother! Her German uncle! Her German governess, who guides her like a helpless child! When will she remember she is English! When will she wake up to the damage she has done? This is greeted by a cheer from his audience. The women s Adelaide looks to Victoria for a response. She doesn’t ge

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: You're confusing stubbornness with strength, my dear. And I warn you: The people will not like you for it! The roar of the crowd’s approval outside, is amplified by louder riot of angry shouting. Which Victoria seems to he INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS. VISITORS’ GALLERY. DAY. 96 Wellington and Melbourne, look down into a rowdy House of Peel is at the Despatch Box below, shouting to make himse (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96 97 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.7

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: With sorrow, I must inform the House that I have been unable to persuade the Queen that her ladies should not solely adhere to the views of my political opponents. I have therefore informed Her Majesty that I am not qualified to form a Government, if I do not enjoy her confidence. Peel sits down. An MP rises from the back on the other si house and looks at the Speaker.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: Sir Francis Baring.

dialogues.speaker: WHIG MEMBER
dialogues.text: Mr. Speaker, are we to understand that the mighty Sir Robert Peel has been frightened off by a few frilly petticoats? This provokes laughter from his own side. Peel rises agai

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Speaker, what frightens me, is to see the Crown used as a shuttlecock in the game of politics. Peel sits again. The whig member remains seated.

dialogues.speaker: WHIG MEMBER
dialogues.text: Which apparently Lord Melbourne plays better than you do, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: Order, Order! More roars of laughter, echoed by Melbourne's supporters INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS. VISITORS’ GALLERY. DAY. 97 Peel enters the gallery to find Wellington waiting for hi them, a quieter House of Commons is emptying.

dialogues.speaker: WELLINGTON
dialogues.text: You have nothing to reproach yourself with, Sir Robert. Your hands were tied. I will make the same point when I speak in the Lords. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 99B
dialogues.text: Phe Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 6th Ang, 2007.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then Peel sees that Melbourne is talking to his supporter member who interrupted Peel in the earlier debate.

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: You should be ashamed of yourself. If the Queen has been foolish, she can plead her youth. You’re old enough to know better.

dialogues.speaker: WHIG MEMBER
dialogues.text: Come, Sir Robert, be honest. What troubles you is that Lord Melbourne is Prime Minister again. He turns aside to Melbourne but speaks to be overheard.

dialogues.speaker: . WHIG MEMBER
dialogues.text: I hate a bad loser.

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: We are all losers in this, Sir. Most especially the Queen. He and Wellington walk away.

dialogues.speaker: WHIG MEMBER
dialogues.text: What a po-faced prig he is.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Maybe. But what if he’s right? For the first time, he sees the damage he’s done. DELETED. INT. ALBERT’S ROOM. ROSENAU CASTLE. MONTAGE. DAY. Albert is writing when he looks at the clock. With a star jumps up, running out of the room, through the castle... INT. PASSAGE. ROSENAU CASTLE. MONTAGE. DAY. Down a passage... INT. STAIRCASE. ROSENAU CASTLE. MONTAGE. DAY. ++. A staircase... page. 72 97 98 99

dialogues.speaker: 99B
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page. 99C INT. BACK HALL. ROSENAU CASTLE. MONTAGE. DAY. 99c --. At last he reaches the back hall, where a Kammerrher through letters.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Anything for me, Gubbenholtz?

dialogues.speaker: KAMMERRHER
dialogues.text: There is, Your Serene Highness, but the Baron always likes -

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’ll take it, myself. Thank you. He removes the envelope from the hesitant servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert is reading his letter, watched by Ernest.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST
dialogues.text: She’s brought down a government over a handful of ladies?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Apparently.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST
dialogues.text: Then she’s a fool.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No. She is not a fool. But she has listened to a fool.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST
dialogues.text: Then she had better change her advisor. Or things will get worse before they get better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The advisor in question, Melbourne, sits with the Queen. the Duchess of Sutherland are with them. Suddenly, as the takes a breath in the dazzling aria...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Melbourne! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The auditorium is stunned. Even the singer falters but re

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Good God! What are we coming to!

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Who was it? I didn't see.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: The Duchess of Montrose. They stare at each other. The Queen is being booed by a d

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: That's the end to her career at Court, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: If I ban everyone who thinks me wrong, you and I will be alone in the ballroom. She studies his face for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And I’m not that sure about you. She looks back towards the stage and spots her mother in further along the Grand Tier. Conroy and Flora are there. seems to look first at the woman who shouted, then at Vic finally to whisper with Conroy and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: God in heaven, is there no way to be rid of them? The question was rhetorical, but Lehzen follows her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t say.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: No, you shouldn't. Victoria is taken aback, but the Duchess tries to explain

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: There’s a story doing the rounds, Ma'am. I’m sure we should give it no credence,

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now will you go on, Lehzen. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: In June, Lady Flora Hastings came home from Scotland with Sir John Conroy. They were three days on the road, alone. She bends to whisper in Victoria’s ear.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What! Lehzen whispers again. Victoria stares as if she were mad

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Just look at her waist. The Queen stares at the hated faces. 102 DELETED. 103 DELETED. 104 INT. VICTORIA’S SITTING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. Queen and Minister are with a smug-looking man in black.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES CLARK
dialogues.text: Let me just say that I hope she is secretly married. Victoria pretends shock but of course she is delighted.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sir James. I appreciate your honesty.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES CLARK
dialogues.text: T do not know it for certain, Your Majesty. I haven't examined her. She would not let me. It is only my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Of course. Thank you, Sir James. The interview is over and he leaves. Victoria gives Melbo satisfied look. He, by contrast, is not happy. 105. DELETED. page. 75 101 102 103 104

dialogues.speaker: 107C
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, &th Aug, 2007. page,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footmen and maids are listening. They scramble as a door open and Lady Flora hurries past without a word. She is i The Duchess stands, helpless in the open doorway. * MONTAGE. INT. ALBERT’‘S ROOM. ROSENAU. NIGHT. 107 Victoria and Albert are writing and reading letters to ea We cut back and forth so rapidly that it is as if they we conversing, but the changes of scene, inside and out, and different costumes show that time is passing. Albert, concerned, is writing at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I worry that your feelings towards your mother may be clouding your judgement. MONTAGE. INT. VICTORIA'S SITTING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. Victoria is at her desk, Albert’s letter in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Surely even my mother might object to the palace being a house of ill repute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert is out walking, reading as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: of course views differ on these things. Madame du Barry was a prostitute and yet the King of France found her company congenial. I however should not! Which makes Albert throw back his head and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria is being dressed by Watson as she reads.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But you've banned Lady Flora from Court, * before anything’s been proved against her. * That is what people dislike. * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 107D
dialogues.text: 108 whe Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, &th Aug, 2007. page.7 CONTINUED: 107c Victoria looks up and speaks aloud, startling Watson.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It will be proved! She reads on.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Could you not wait until it is? MONTAGE. INT. ALBERT’S ROOM. ROSENAU. DAY. . 107D Now Albert is being dressed by his valet. He is also read

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now they tell me that Lady Flora means to fight it out in public. Which is too typical and vulgar to be believed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria is reading the answer from Albert.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It may be vulgar, or typical, my dearest Victoria, but it does not make her guilty. She half crumples the letter, throwing it down. Then she startled by Lehzen who, still as ever, stands in the door

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: There is a swelling, no doubt about it, but no bigger than it was a month ago. Lehzen sees Albert’s letter. It does not please her.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Do you think it was all a trick to catch us out?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Tf it was, then it worked... Victoria is as cold as ice. Clearly she blames Lehzen. An has been slipped under the door. Lehzen picks it up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: 109B
dialogues.text: 109¢ The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: From your mother. Victoria takes it but does not answer or even look at her governess, who goes. Victoria sits for a moment, alone. D been watching and now he jumps up, but she pushes him awa

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh, get off me! The dog, hurt and bewildered, shrinks back as her mistres to the window, with the letter from her mother in her han not see her face as she reads.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My dearest child, You will not let me come to you, and that I may deserve. But however you resent me, however I have failed, I am still, and always, your mother. What troubles you, troubles me. What pleases you, pleases me. I love you, and my only prayer is that, one day, you will understand how much. Good night, mein Liebling, your own Mama. The candles lend a ghostly quality to the room. Below, an hover. Victoria sits, her head in her hands, and starts t gently at first, but then with racking sobs. MONTAGE. INT. KING LEOPOLD'S LIBRARY. LAEKEN PALACE. DAY. Leopold, Stockmar and Albert study a newspaper. A letter headed “Grave Injustice.” It is signed by Lady Flora Hast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The letter, cut out, is pinned on the clippings wall. MONTAGE. INT. KING LEOPOLD’S LIBRARY. LAEKEN PALACE. DAY. King Leopold is looking at a vicious cartoon of Victoria The Duchess of Kent and Lady Flora. He covers his face as the newspaper to Albert. MONTAGE. INT. A WALL IN LONDON. DAY. 109c The cartoon is being pinned to the wall.  109D MONTAGE. INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS. DAY. 110 aii 112 113 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page. 79

dialogues.speaker: 109D
dialogues.text: Another cartoon, this one of Melbourne and Victoria tramp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flora in the dust. Except that it is not on the wall, but Melbourne’s hands. He holds a newspaper and stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I’ve had a letter from King Leopold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melbourne and Victoria are walking. He waits to hear.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: He proposes another visit by Prince Albert.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: What have you answered?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Nothing yet. And now, at last, the Minister questions his own judgemen

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Perhaps you should let him come. She is visibly relieved by this but also defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hostile crowd has gathered outside the palace. Some new making them angry. As usual, Edward Oxford is among them.

dialogues.speaker: DELETED. 112
dialogues.text: INT. VICTORTA’S DRAWING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. 113 The Queen is listening as two actors play a scene from ‘R with the Duchess of Sutherland and some ladies.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: Not all the water in the rough rude sea can wash the balm from an anointed king. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113 114 115 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: At this moment, Duchess of Sutherland is amazed to see Co hovering in the doorway. She breaks away to go over to hi talk, the scene continues. *

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: Sir John, what on earth are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: I must speak to the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: You know that’s quite impossible. He lowers his voice. A roar from the crowd outside sends rippling through the room. During this, the acting contin the Duchess returns to her chair next to the Queen. *

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND .
dialogues.text: Lady Flora Hastings is dying. * Victoria turns to her, aghast. *

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: It’s true. Cancer of the stomach. Victoria is stunned. She stares at the Duchess. The actor agony. Hesitantly, glancing at each other, they continue. There is a crash. A brick has been thrown through the win showering the company with glass. The actress screams, bu looks back at the Duchess with horrible clarity.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What have I done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen kneels, alone in the vast abbey. An equerry, a watchman and the Duchess of Sutherland stand in a side ai watching. Victoria, eyes heavenward, begs for forgiveness INT. LADY FLORA’S BEDROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. 115 The light is dim and the curtains closed. Victoria is in doorway. The shrunken figure of Lady Flora is on the bed. woman standing by her stiffens as Victoria approaches.

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: You remember my mother, Your Majesty. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Indeed. Lady Hastings.

dialogues.speaker: MARCHIONESS OF HASTINGS
dialogues.text: Your Majesty. She curtsies slightly, her manner as stiff as a board.

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: Would you leave us, Mama? Just for a moment. The Marchioness is reluctant but she goes.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: She hates me. Since this is clearly true, Flora does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I have come to apologise. I wish what I have done could be undone.

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: But it cannot be undone. They stare at each other, Queen and invalid. Then Flora t painful breath.

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: Well, well... I am not on my deathbed because of your cruelty... She studies the Queen, who is truly at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: We never liked each other much, you and I. At this, Victoria makes to protest, but Flora cuts her of

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, Ma’am, but you will allow that honesty is the privilege of the dying. Which Victoria does not disagree with.

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: You thought me cold and snobbish and lodged in Sir John Conroy's pocket. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 115 116 ‘The Youmg Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 6th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She waits but Victoria says nothing, because this is true silent acceptance seems to please Lady Flora, who nods.

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: I thought you naive and headstrong and too young for the position you occupy. And we were both right in part. But not entirely.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Recent events would seem to bear out your verdict, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: You have been foolish. Your devotion to Lord Melbourne and your anger at your mother both corrupted your judgement. But you have also shown the world your strength. This is difficult for Victoria but she accepts the critic

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I think the world would use a different term.

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: For good or i11, you've brought down a Government, Ma'am! We've almost had riot in the streets! There’s power in you! In you, and not just in the Crown. More power than I ever imagined. Leave off these silly games of favouritism or revenge, and harness it!

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Will they still let me?

dialogues.speaker: LADY FLORA
dialogues.text: Your subjects may be angry, but they have not done with you yet. Just let your childish anger die with me. Turn your mind to the work ahead... For you are still at the start of a great adventure. The two enemies look at each other. There is peace in Flo guilt in Victoria's. The melody of “The Swan Song” is hea played on a solo piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headline, “LADY FLORA HASTINGS DEAD!” is pinned up. The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VICTORIA'S SITTING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY
dialogues.text: 117 Seen from behind, Victoria is seated at her piano. We hea Schubert’s melody but, as we close in, we realize that sh playing. She’s looking at Schubert’s music, as she hugs h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria in sober mood is with Melbourne. There are men a on the pavement but no cheers.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: T am not forgiven yet.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Not yet but soon. Just wait for unseasonal weather or the news of an elopement, and all will be forgotten. She looks at him. Is she waking up at last?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You don’t have a very high cpinion of ordinary people, do you, Lord Melbourne?

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: With respect, I have lived much longer than your Majesty. She does not answer this. Instead, she thinks for a momen

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I said once I did not understand whose task it was to see to the public welfare. For once, he does not jest. He wants her to understand. *

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Ma’am, in my lifetime I have seen what happens when the rabble is empowered. Believe me, they do not profit from it, any more than the kings they overthrow, and - eH OF

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Lord Melbourne. I want a report on living conditions, on parish benefit, on housing... all of it. And by the end of the month. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Melbourne looks at this young woman, knowing what this me child pupil is growing up and he will lose her.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Very good, Your Majesty. 118 INT. ALBERT’S ROOM. ROSENAU CASTLE. COBURG. DAY. 118 A valet packs under Albert's supervision, watched by Erne

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST
dialogues.text: After what Melbourne and Conroy have done to ruin her, she'll welcome your proposal like the sun in May.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: She won't. For I can’t propose. Ernest doesn’t understand what his brother is talking abo

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: She must ask me. I cannot ask her. How absurd is that? But Ernest has something important to say.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST
dialogues.text: When you get there, don’t be a spy or Uncle Leopold’s puppet. It’s your life, Albert. Live it. For yourself and for Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Our uncle wouldn’t thank you for that.

dialogues.speaker: ERNEST
dialogues.text: I don’t care. I don’t love him. Albert is more touched by this than he can say. Awkwardly throws a playful punch at his brother. Ernest returns it. they abandon the pretence and hug each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria walks with Lehzen in a gallery. Victoria smiles Lehzen smiles back, relieved to be forgiven. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 120 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: His Serene Highness Prince Albert of Saxe— Coburg and Gotha. The Prince enters the gallery in a travelling costume of coat, with tight, pale, buckskin trousers and high boots. climbs, around his legs weave two superb greyhounds. It i impossible for a male human to be this handsome...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria paces restlessly in the pretty little room. On a two or three open, red boxes, with crests on the lids and dense with writing and figures and orders, spilling out. a noise in the passage and hastily sits on a sofa. The do and Albert enters. He is clearly as nervous as she is. *

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I only just got your note. I was riding.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I envy you. * Smiling, she nods at the paper detritus on her writing ta

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Sit. Please... Here. He does. They are side by side now. But she is still not to steer the conversation around. Nor is he.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: The park is marvellous.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I'm so pleased you like it. I do want you to be quite at home... Is this it? Maybe. He looks at her, waiting. Here goes.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I think you must be aware why I wished you to come here... Because it would make me happier than anything - too happy, really - if you’d agree to what I wish... Now, surely, it’s acceptable for him to weigh in.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And stay with you? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120 121 122 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And stay with me.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And marry you?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And marry me. These last speeches have come out in a kind of shared, ga tumbled rush, but they have reached their destination and passionate relief as he takes her in his arms and, at las her properly. INT. CHAPEL ROYAL. ST. JAMES’S. DAY. 121 They stand before the altar, Victoria and Albert watched our principal characters. The Archbishop presides. *

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: I now pronounce you man and wife. Victoria blushes with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria is in bed alone. There is a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Come in. The door opens and there is Albert in a dressing gown. He door behind him. It is a moment of exquisite, sweet awkwa walks to the window, peering out.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I feel more at ease in Windsor. It reminds me of Rosenau. She looks at him. He is fumbling.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: It's much larger, of course.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I haven't always been so fond of it... I will be now... He comes and sits on the bed. Gently, he takes her hands. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 123 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: . ALBERT
dialogues.text: Alone at last. They laugh, nervously. Then he becomes serious.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I must tell you that I'll do everything in my power not to disappoint you. Use me. Draw on me for help, with any task that lies ahead. There is something awkward here. Their expectations do no

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Shhhh. Just love me. Now. She takes his face in her two hands and kisses him. This things at least will clearly not be a problem. INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. 123 Outside the window is the sound of cheering. The Duchess her desk. Conroy stands nearby holding a letter.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: It’s not complicated. It says you have no money.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: But that’s impossible... Isn’t it? You would have known if...

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Why did you open it? I always deal with the letters from your banker - There is a shout from the cheering crowd outside.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Can‘t they keep them quiet? Someone should tell them the Queen is at Windsor. He walks to the window and looks down, suddenly pensive.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: How changeable they are... They hate you. They love you. They hate you.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: They didn’t hate her. They punished her. But they never hated her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007. Page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks at the picture of herself and her lost child.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: And now she is a bride and back on top. Until the next mistake. He sighs. When he speaks, his tone is genuinely wondering

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: What on earth have I done with my life? He glances at her, aimost as if she were a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: I had many gifts, you know. As a boy, I was tipped for success.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: You have served me faithfully. He looks at her, this foolish woman. The thought that thi he has achieved is suddenly preposterous.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: And what is that? For a second, she says nothing. Then, with one wide gestu sweeps everything on her desk to the ground with a loud c papers, candles, inkwells, books, everything. Conroy is s stunned. In silence, she stands and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: . INT. VICTORIA'S BEDROOM. WINDSOR CASTLE. DAY. 124
dialogues.text: Albert is asleep, watched with wonder by Victoria. She re to arrange his hair. He opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Now I know I am quite married.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And when we’re old, and surrounded by our children, we will remember this as the day our lives began. He strokes her cheek tenderly. But she protests.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Not too surrounded, please. And not too soon. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 124 125 126 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Oh? I should warn you that I am expecting a very large family! And he seizes her in a tangle of sheets and giggles. INT. PASSAGE. WINDSOR CASTLE. DAY. Watson is walking down the passage with some linen, when surprised by Lehzen, standing motionless in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Have you woken Her Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: No, M’m.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Don't you think you should?

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: No, M'm. Not this morning, I don’t. She walks on, leaving Lehzen seething with jealousy. INT. VICTORIA’S BEDROOM. WINDSOR. DAY. page. 69 124 125 126 Victoria sits on the edge of the bed in her nightdress, a kneels before her, rolling her stockings up her legs.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Let’s take a little tour together and visit Scotland. I hear if any part of Britain is like Germany, it’s the highlands of Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Yes, we must. One day.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No. I mean straight away. Now.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Only for a few weeks. You're a bride. They can’t expect you back before that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 126 127 128 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Dearest, I may be a bride but I'm also a queen. I cannot be away more than three days at the most. This is disappointing. But he doesn’t wish to spoil thing Instead, he starts to take her stocking off again.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Well, if we've only got three days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gallop through the Great Park, and they’re an impres she riding side-saddle in her velvet habit and plumed hat Albert in his romantic costume. They rein in. Later, they’re alone by a stream, horses tethered nearby. head is in Victoria’s lap and she strokes his hair.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I ought to warn you of my chief weakness. I never leave enough time for play.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: But you’ll have all the time in the world. I wish I could say the same. * Before he can quite register this, they are kissing and l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen is in bed waiting for Albert to join her. He co removing his dressing gown.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: We really should end the quarrel with your * mother. * He climbs into bed. Her answer, when it comes, is very ca

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I cannot while Sir John Conroy remains in her household. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISTONS, &th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Then we’ll get rid of him. She seems to study his face, which he takes for agreement

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Our power lies in our example, and we can hardly present ourselves to the British as an ideal family if we're torn apart by Civil War! Again, he smiles, half joking. For a moment, she is silen she does speak, her tone is totally altered.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: They warned me of this.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: of what?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Let me make one thing clear. I will not be governed. I will not be managed. I will not be controlled!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Can't I have an opinion?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No! Yes, but... for eighteen years I could * not breathe, I could not dress or bathe or * walk down stairs without permission! I’m not a child and I will never live that way again!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t want a child! Quite the reverse!

dialogues.speaker: . VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Then do not lecture me on politics or my mother or anything else! I may be Queen of England. But you are not the King! There is a deep pool of silence. *

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Well, now that’s clear, may I ask what exactly am I supposed to do? It is a good point.  129 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria works at her Red Boxes. Lehzen and the Duchess o Sutherland embroider. Albert strokes Dash and reads a new Victoria stops, biting the end of her pen.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: What is it? The Queen shakes her head, laying the document aside.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Just a question for Lord M.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Could I. help?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It‘ll keep. She does not see how dismissive this is, in front of the exasperation, Albert stands and goes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Why are these windows so dirty? I can hardly see out.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Same as the fires, I’m afraid. The departments can’t agree to wash inside and out at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Then why not do something about it?

dialogues.speaker: . DUCHESS OF SUTHERLAND
dialogues.text: I quite agree.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Because it’s the way things are done here and it’s worked well for many years.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, we live in a filthy, freezing house.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: We live as guests of the Queen. It is a reprimand which he does not take kindly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 129 130 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Baroness, for reminding me I am a guest here. With a curt bow, he leaves. Victoria stands to follow.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Let him go. It always takes time to get used to a new uniform. At this, the Duchess looks at Lehzen with real dislike, w Victoria sees. And it makes her think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria is walking with Queen Adelaide.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: How’s Albert settling in?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Why? What have you heard? Naturally, this is an answer in itself. Out it comes.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I simply cannot please him. Nothing's ever right. All I hear is a litany of my mistakes from dawn to dusk. He says Lord Melbourne controls me. He says Lehzen controls me. It seems everyone controls me except him! And he never stops complaining he has nothing to do, but Lehzen says ~ She breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: What does Lehzen say?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Only that most men would love a life of leisure and he should be grateful... She deesn’t mean to be unkind.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Oh no. Anyone could see that. Her tone makes Victoria look at her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: A man who does no work becomes ridiculous. And a poor man with a rich wife must work twice as hard as the rest. Besides, you've chosen well.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: My uncle William chose well. But you didn’t take on half his duties.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: You don't know that. You don’t know what I did. Adelaide sighs. For once, Victoria is not sure about this

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: He says he wants to reorganise the way the palaces are run.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Then for Heaven's sake, let him! And do please tell dear Lehzen I said so. Victoria locks genuinely relieved, which is encouraging. 131 INT. ANTE ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. A servant is laying the table when Albert walks in. The Prince

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What is this for?

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: The Red Room Dinner, Sir. For the officers guarding the King.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What King?

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: King George III, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And how often do we provide this dinner for a king who has been dead for twenty years?

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: Every night, Sir. absorbs this information. page.94 130

132 133 134 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th aug, 2007. page.9 INT. VICTORIA’S SITTING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. 132 Albert enters, disturbing the servants at work. One man r unused candles from a large chandelier which has been low

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Those candles are brand new. * The man is silent. The other servants look nervous as the digests another massive waste. He makes a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert is walking along when he sees Lehzen laughing with holds a newspaper. They fold it when they see him.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Something amusing?

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: Nothing, Your Royal Highness. But the Prince holds out his hand for the paper. A cartoo Albert counting scrubbing brushes: “One brush per housema more and Parliament will be told!” He hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: People always hate change.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: That's true, Baroness, but mercifully, few of them hate it as much as you de. He goes, followed by the cold and jealous eyes of Lehzen. INT. VICTORIA’S BEDROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. NIGHT. 134 Albert's face is as still as stone. So is Victoria's. The is vibrant. Is this another battle’s aftermath?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You're sure? She nods and, in a wider shot, Albert walks forward and k Pulling her to him, he kisses her stomach. The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page. 135 INT. VICTORIA'S DRAWING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. The fire burns brightly. Albert and Victoria are with the of Kent, Lehzen, Melbourne and Adelaide. They clap and ch

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Ma'am. You are officially * an ancestor. * Victoria laughs, as Adelaide hugs her warmly. Seeing this Duchess rushes forward, overwhelmed with delight.

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Mein liebling! You'll say at once if there’s anything you need! She tries to hold Victoria, who pulls back slightly.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Heavens. Don’t crush me, Mama. The Duchess, flattened, retreats from the group, looking her reticule. Albert comes over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going already?

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: I can never leave too early for my daughter... Anyway, I’ve a lot on my mind.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Something I could help with?

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: Just boring things.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Boring things are what sons-in-law are for. But she kisses him and goes. Melbourne has been listening

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: And there you have your opening. For your next task. If you’ll take my advice ~ Albert cuts him off with a pleasant, easy smile. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 135 136 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.9

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Lord Melbourne, forgive me but you seem to have confused me with a member of your club. I am not your drinking companion or your whist partner, I am the husband of your Sovereign. As such, I will make my own decisions and I neither seek nor invite your advice. Good evening. Albert walks off, leaving Melbourne speechless. INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. 136 Open ledgers, dense with figures, fill the screen.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I cannot believe I’m being subjected to this interrogation! Albert sits at a table piled high with account books, wat furious Conroy and the Duchess.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You're not being subjected to anything, Sir John. You have been in charge of the Duchess’s finances for many years. Indeed, you have made public statements testifying to their health.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: I have!

dialogues.speaker: DUCHESS OF KENT
dialogues.text: And I am so grateful... She glances at her implacable son-in-law. She regrets thi she would beg for mercy but Conroy spurns her glances. Pe because he has nothing more to lose.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: All I am asking is that you will be so good as to tell us exactly where the money has gone? Conroy’s flushed, furious face tells us precisely where t has gone. But the tragedy here belongs to the Duchess, wh struggles to prevent her tears from flowing. She has lost daughter’s love. And all on account of this worthless man The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 138 139 Victoria is walking down a passage when she stops short. opened and Conroy comes out. He is dressed for travelling stands stock still. For a moment, neither speaks. Then...

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: As a point of curiosity, would you ever have accepted my help? If I had managed things differently?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Not if my life should depend on it. Victoria’s face and voice could both be carved from stone

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Sir John.

dialogues.speaker: CONROY
dialogues.text: Goodbye... Your Majesty. At long last, the battle is over and Victoria has won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coach is loaded up. Conroy storms out and climbs in. Th takes up the reins. The vehicle rumbles off. From a windo Duchess looks down as her former favourite is swept out o life. Further along the facade, Victoria also stares down devil of her childhood departs. Albert joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a reception, Albert is with Wellington and Sir Robert Victoria and the Duchess of Sutherland walk over to join

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I've been boring Sir Robert and the Duke with my ideas for encouraging the Arts.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Does Sir Robert care for such frivolity? Her tone is soft. But hostile. His reply, if anything, is (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Young victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th ang, 2007.

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: I have many interests, Ma'am. And my Government would support the Prince’s plans wholeheartedly.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Your Government? What Government is this?

dialogues.speaker: PEEL
dialogues.text: I meant if I should be fortunate enough to form another Government, Ma'am... Albert decides to throw some oil onto these troubled wate

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And when he does, there'll be no repeat of the old problem. Some of your ladies have already agreed to resign. Sir Robert will ask for no more change than that. page. 99 139

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria looks at him and then glances at the Duchess who if even she were in on this decision. Victoria is silent pleasantly. Peel smiles back. 140 INT. VICTORIA'S BEDROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. NIGHT. The Queen is incandescent with anger.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: How dare you speak in that way to me before them! How dare you talk across me as if I were a child!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I did no such thing!

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh no? You've sorted this! You've sorted that! You and Sir Robert! You and the Duke! And all without reference to me!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I thought you'd be pleased.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what you thought! You thought T was a woman, to be petted and passed over and ignored! 140 (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Would it were so simple! Then we might avoid more scandals of your making!

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Have you lost your mind? But now he is getting angry. And his anger matches hers.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Do you wonder at it? Less than three years on the Throne and you and your precious Melbourne have pushed the Monarchy to the brink of an abyss!

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What is my Prime Minister to you! I’ve told you before and I tell you again: You are my husband here and that is ail!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: It's quite enough, believe me!

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I will not have my role usurped! I wear the Crown and if there are mistakes, they will be my mistakes! And no one else will make them! No one! Not even you! He starts to answer. Then he stops.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’m leaving. Before you excite yourself and harm the child.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: If I do, it will be your fault! Just like the baby! Which, by the way, I did not want! And you will go when I dismiss you! He is shocked by her cruelty. He walks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: We'll talk tomorrow when you are calmer... and feeling more grown up!

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You may not go! I order you to stay here in this room! He continues and puts his hand on the doorknob. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 140 141 142 143 144 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I am your Queen and I am telling you to stay! She is screaming at him. He speaks softly in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Victoria. He is gone and she is left enraged, humiliated, bewildere EXT. ENTRANCE COURT. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. There is an open carriage waiting, complete with equerrie couple of mounted guards. The Queen and Prince Albert are ready for a drive. But no speaking. At last she addresses him.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: There’s no necessity for you to accompany me.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’ve said I'1l come with you. So I will come with you. They say nothing more and climb into the carriage togethe apart. The guards swap a quick look. The coachman takes u reins and they move off. DELETED. DELETED. EXT. CONSTITUTION HILL. DAY. The carriage bowls up the leafy road. Riders in the park page. 101 140 141 142 143 144 over to wave. So do pedestrians. It is a happy scene, but iciness between the Royal couple, as they hiss at each ot

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: For pity’s sake, smile. Or they’11 think we have quarrelled,

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Then they’1l be right! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 144 145 146 147 148 149 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, @th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But Albert has noticed something. He seizes his wife's ar outraged at being pulled backwards against the seat and s to free herself.

dialogues.speaker: / VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What! Edward Oxford, is aiming a gun at the carriage. He shoots INT. DUCHESS’S DRAWING ROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. 145 The Duchess of Kent suddenly looks up from her sewing. An close-up shows the hairs on her arm standing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford fires again. Men throw themselves upon him, pinnin the ground. The riders, men and women, angry and excited, tangled guard around the vehicle as the coachman yells at horses and the whole pack gallops headlong for home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert is half dragged, half carried through the hall at speed, followed by Victoria. Lehzen hurries in.

dialogues.speaker: LEHZEN
dialogues.text: What's happened? What’s he done this time?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Not now, Lehzen! She races on, leaving the governess alone among the runni servants and officers, as panic streams through the Palac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door of a dingy, back street room is forced open and police officers enter, followed by a harassed landlady.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: What're you doing with Mr Oxford’s things? What's happened? What’s he done? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 149 150 151 the Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The officers walk in and look around. One notices somethi him. Then they all look up at the ceiling. Every cartoon, headline we have seen pinned up, is on this ceiling. * INT. VICTORIA’S BEDROOM. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. 150

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start on a CU of paper. Pull back and reveal Albert in be newspaper. He looks dazed and tired and his arm is bandag James Clark stands back and takes the paper out of Albert

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES CLARK
dialogues.text: There’s nothing more I can do here. The Prince needs rest. The others file out with him, leaving only Victoria. She the bed, with her husband’s hand in hers. He looks at her

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t think he was a very good shot. Thank heaven. They laugh a little with relief. Then she grows serious.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You saved my life. *

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: If I did, I had two very good reasons. * First, I am replaceable and you are not -

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You're not replaceable to me. ALBERT . Second, you're the only wife I've got or ever will have. You are my whole existence. And I will love you until my last breath. Her eyes fill. She leans down to kiss him with all her he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria is with Melbourne in the gardens.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: We'll lose the vote tonight. I felt you should hear it from me... How is the Prince? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Much better. We’re told the man was mad. Is that reassuring? I can’t decide.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: May I be honest? She stops, querying him with a look.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: Even a politician can be honest sometimes. She nods, taking his arm as they begin to walk.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: The years spent in Your Majesty’s company won’t be repeated. They’ve meant a good deal to me. More perhaps than anything else in my long career... My guidance may not always have been faultless, and I am sorry for it. But I speak now as a true friend.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: The Prince is a good man. A better man than any of us knew. Victoria is surprised at this, which he sees.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: He does not think as well of me, but my vanity is not the issue here. He is able and clever. And faithful. Let him share your work. Take him into your confidence.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You know King Leopold plans to use him to influence our policy? Her tone is quite matter-of-fact. He is amazed.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: I know that. So does the Foreign Office. But nobody thinks you do. Victoria shrugs slightly.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Every suitor would have come with strings attached. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: idl 152 153 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aag, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Melbourne smiles. The innocent, young girl has become a w knowledgeable woman.

dialogues.speaker: MELBOURNE
dialogues.text: One other thing, Ma'am. Which you will not want to hear...

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Try me. These days, I value the truth more than I did. In recognition of this, Melbourne takes her hand and rais gently to his lips. Which she allows, and then slides her through his as they stroll along by the lake, the old Sta the end of his career, the young Queen at the start of he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another carriage has been loaded up with luggage for a lo journey. This one holds the dour figure of Baroness Lehze looks grimly ahead as the vehicle pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria is watching this second departure with Albert wh in a sling. She quickly wipes a tear away.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I needed her so much as a child.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And soon you’ll have a child who needs you. He holds her to him, kissing her tenderly. Then he looks something. She follows his gaze. *

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I hope you don’t mind, I’ve had your desk * brought in. * It's true. Their desks sit side by side. She smiles. *

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It'll be so much easier to do the boxes or see the ministers, if your papers are here as well as mine.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Don’t I have any say in this? * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 153 154 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He looks serious but then smiles. She playfully hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leopold is with Stockmar. He is holding a blue letter, sh rage.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: This is intolerable! He writes that he would prefer not to talk politics in his letters but only to discuss news of the family! He’s copying her! Stockmar shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. No, they sound alike because they think alike.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Spare me the language of a ladies’ novelette! But the Baron knows he has to help his Master through thi

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: Sir, we must accept it. The birds have flown.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: I will not accept it! I have planned this marriage for twenty years! And now, because of a simple girl and a callow youth, I’m to accept that I have failed!

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: On the contrary, Your Majesty, you are to be congratulated... The wizened, enigmatic, old Baron is smiling for once.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKMAR
dialogues.text: For I would say that the whole affair has been a very great success. The opening scene music theme starts to play as we hear:

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I’ll be the judge of that!  is5 156 The Young Victoria, PINK REVISIONS, 8th Aug, 2007. page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse is at the doorway, carrying a baby. Albert goes t takes his daughter in his arms. He walks to Victoria, acr room, and gives her the child to hold.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: If you trust me in this matter, you will * thank me. Albert kisses his wife and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I doubt it. He smiles as the Duchess of Kent walks in. With his back Victoria, Albert gives the Duchess a wink and leaves. The stands enjoying the tableau of her daughter holding the c Queen looks up. After a moment, she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Don’t stand by the door, Mama. Come in. And we leave this mother and daughter, neither quite so a really together. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria and Albert are walking together, arm in arm, dow passage. They are in evening dress but they are talking a laughing. Then they come to a pair of doors, stop, straig and nod to the footmen to open them. In that fraction of a second, they have turned themselves Sovereign and her Consort. The company bows and curtseys hold their positions in the doorway, calm, dignified, the Royal couple. They could be posing for a Winterhalter por freeze frame. It took Prince Albert ten more years before Victoria and mother were finally, and happily, at peace. * victoria and Albert reigned together for twenty years, an together they would champion reform in every part of thei expanding empire. After Albert's death in 1861, on Victor orders, his rooms were kept unchanged and his clothes lai out each day, for the rest of her life. Their nine childr all married and among their descendants are the Royal (CONTINUED)
